results.title: The Breakfast club
results.creator_credit: John Hughes, Ned Tanen and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: John Hughes wrote and directed this film which was to become the quintessential high school drama of the 80s. Claire, the princess; Andrew, the jock; John, the criminal; Brian, the nerdy brain; and Alison, the basket case are all faced with spending nine hours together in Saturday detention. They begin the day as strangers having nothing in common, but as the day progresses, they slowly develop a bond in recognising that they are not as different as their places in the high school caste system would have them believe. Cast includes: Emilio Estevez, Judd Nelson, Molly Ringwald, Anthony Michael Hall, Ally Sheedy and Paul Gleason.

results.title: Project X
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Kaplan, Lawrence Lasker, Walter Parkes and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Pilot Jimmy Garrett (Mathew Broderick) finds himself working on a special military assignment as punishment when he is grounded for misconduct. His mission is to teach chimpanzees to fly through the use of flight simulators, and he quickly discovers an affinity with the animals who he begins communicating with. When he befriends researcher Teri (Helen Hunt) and her number one student, a chimpanzee called Virgil she has successfully taught sign language to, Garrett discovers something that wasn’t in the brief - the real purpose of “Project X” is to test the limits of human endurance by subjecting the experimental primates to radiation. Teri and Jimmy are forced to question their loyalties to science, their careers, and the animals that have become friends. Cast also includes Bill Sadler, Johnny Ray McGhee and Jonathan Stark.

results.title: Arlington Road
results.creator_credit: Mark Pellington, Peter Samuelson, Marc Samuelson, Tom Gorai and Lakeshore Entertainment
results.brief_description: After his FBI agent wife is killed by an extremist group, college professor Michael Faraday moves his son and himself to a new neighborhood, to make a fresh start. Driving home from work one day he saves the life of a boy, the son of his neighbours Oliver and Cheryl Lang. Becoming friends with the Langs’, Michael’s life begins to improve, he has a new girlfriend, his son is happy, and he has a job teaching American History at the local college - specialising in terrorism and extremist activities. Soon he begins to notice details of Oliver’s stories don’t add up. Are his neighbours as normal as they seem? Cast includes Jeff Bridges, Tim Robbins and Joan Cusack.

results.title: Akira Kurosawa's Dreams = Dreams
results.creator_credit: Akira Kurosawa, Steven Spielberg, Mike Y Inoue, Hisao Kurosawa, Akira Kurosawa USA Productions and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This Japanese-American co-production can be regarded as Kurosawa’s last personal philosophic and cinematic testament as he explores in eight vignettes the cost of war, the perils of nuclear warfare, and above all man’s need to harmonise with nature. It is Kurosawa’s belief that, ‘Man is genius when he dreams’, and his visions are here, superbly realised in Takao Sato and Masaharu Ueda’s sunny cinematography. In Japanese with English subtitles. Cast includes Martin Scorsese and Akire Terao.

results.title: Bhowani Junction
results.creator_credit: George Cukor, Pandro S. Berman and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: In what is considered by many fans to be her best performance, Ava Gardner stars as the heroine Victoria Jones, a woman forced to make some painful life decisions in post Colonial India. Her relationship with three men; Colonel Savage (Stewart Granger) a British military man in charge of protecting trains crossing Bhowani Junction, fellow Anglo-Indian Patrick Taylor (Bill Travers), and Sikh communist Peter Illing who befriends Victoria after she kills a potential rapist in self defence - challenging her to assess where her loyalties and ethnicity lie. Adapted from the novel by John Masters.

results.title: The Purple plain
results.creator_credit: Robert Parrish, John Bryan, Two Cities Films and Rank Organisation Film Productions
results.brief_description: This psychological wartime drama set in Burma was based on the novel by H.E. Bates. A Canadian pilot (Gregory Peck) and two comrades-in-arms crash in the Burmese wilds. The three men are forced to hack their way through the jungle to safety, surrounded on all sides by the Japanese. The pilot’s subordinates don’t completely trust their leader, and not without reason - his nerves have been at breaking point for months. Faced with this severe test of courage and endurance, he must muster the physical and mental resources to lead his men to safety. Cast includes Maurice Denham, Win Min Than, Lyndon Brook, Anthony Bushell and Josephone Griffin.

results.title: The Hill
results.creator_credit: Sydney Lumet, Kenneth Hyman, Seven Arts and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Five British soldiers, all accused of crimes during wartime, are introduced to a prison war camp in Northern Africa during World War II. Run by a tyrannical and old-fashioned Seargent Major (Harry Andrews), the centre of the prison is a man-made “hill” on which the prisoners are routinely punished and tortured. The five new men all represent a cross-section of British society; all find themselves victimised by a sadistic prison guard (played by Ian Hendry) who uses the rhetoric of Empire and Victorian authority to brutalise the men physically and spiritually. When his victimisation goes one step too far, the prisoners must choose between staying silent and winning their freedom, or choosing to support Joe Robert (Sean Connery) who wants to see justice being served. Lumet directs this film with vicious energy, and it is an unrelenting and powerful indictment of the damage that a harsh hierarchical institution can do to men. It’s tough-mindedness and gruelling scenes of punishment and exploitation make it now seem a movie far ahead of its time. Cast also includes Sir Michael Redgrave. Based on a play by Ray Rigby.

results.title: Autumn tale = Conte d'Automne
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Sofilmka, Rhone-Alpes Cinema, La Sept Cinema and Canal+
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons”.
The final instalment in Eric Rohmer’s “Tales of the four seasons” quartet of films looks at a later life romance. Friends and family of the widowed Magali decide that it is time she was matched up with a new lover. Beautifully filmed in the vineyards of the Rhone Valley. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Spanish prisoner
results.creator_credit: David Mamet, Jean Doumanian, Jean Doumanian Productions and Sweetland Films BV
results.brief_description: Joe Ross (Campbell Scott) is the unworldly inventor of “the process,” an undisclosed mathematical formula that has a huge monetary potential for the company he works at. However, his boss is unwilling to discuss the personal bonus Joe believes he has coming to him. While on a business trip to the Caribbean, he runs into Jimmy Dell (Steve Martin), a mysterious, rich stranger who offers him a few tips on life and business. This meeting marks the beginning of his spiral into a labyrinthine world of shady characters, plot twists and surprise reversals, where nothing is what it appears to be and nobody can be trusted. As in “House of Games” (1987), Mamet’s first film as a director, the elaborate con game visited on the innocent victim in “The Spanish Prisoner” completely shatters their sense of equilibrium. Trust proves Joe’s undoing, faith in humanity his tragic flaw. As with many other of Mamet’s films, an underlying theme running throughout the film is that of the immorality of the corporate world that rewards those who act ruthlessly and punishes those who hold to a code of ethics. Cast also includes Ben Gazzara, Felicity Huffman and Rebecca Pidgeon.

results.title: The Dinner game = Le Diner de cons
results.creator_credit: Francis Veber, Alain Poire and Sharmill Films
results.brief_description: Pierre Brochant (Thierry Lhermitte), a wealthy publisher, yuppie and art collector is into competitions of a completely different nature. The challenge between he and his friends is to bring an “idiot” to their regular Wednesday dinner, for an evening of culinary delights and amusing conversation at the cost of these supposedly intellectually inferior diners. Pierre’s friend thinks he is onto a winner with a boomerang salesman; Pierre thinks he is in with a good chance with Finance Ministry accountant, Francois Pignon (Jacques Villeret), a matchstick construction enthusiast. The viewer is never privy to seeing one of these dinner farces in action, instead Pierre finds himself spending time in his apartment with Francois, who kindly offers to help his new friend whose wife has just left him, and who is also now incapacitated by an injured back courtesy of a dodgy golf swing. In the space of a few short hours Pierre has a dinner party for two, with he being the sole witness to Francois’ stupidity and bearing the brunt of his actions as meddling with “idiots” moves into a different realm. Cast also includes Francis Huster, Alexandra Vandernoot and Daniel Prevost. In French with English subtitles.
